author: pcgeek86
body:
Steps to reproduce
------------------

1. Run `Invoke-WebRequest -Uri https://internalwebsite.local` (actual URL hidden for security)

Expected behavior
-----------------

Web request succeeds, similar to how the web browser (eg. Google Chrome, Firefox, Safari) successfully opens the secured page.

Actual behavior
---------------

An exception is thrown:

```
Invoke-WebRequest : An error occurred while sending the request.
At line:1 char:1
+ Invoke-WebRequest https://internalwebsite.local
+ ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
    + CategoryInfo          : InvalidOperation: (Method: GET, Re...rShell/6.0.0
}:HttpRequestMessage) [Invoke-WebRequest], HttpRequestException
    + FullyQualifiedErrorId : WebCmdletWebResponseException,Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.InvokeWebRequestCommand
```

When I dig into the exception, I find:

```
PS /> $error[0].Exception.InnerException
Peer certificate cannot be authenticated with given CA certificates
```

Environment data
----------------

```powershell
Name                           Value
----                           -----
PSVersion                      6.0.0-alpha
PSEdition                      Core
PSCompatibleVersions           {1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0...}
BuildVersion                   3.0.0.0
GitCommitId                    v6.0.0-alpha.14
CLRVersion
WSManStackVersion              3.0
PSRemotingProtocolVersion      2.3
SerializationVersion           1.1.0.1
```

Cheers,
**Trevor Sullivan**
Docker Captain
Microsoft MVP: Cloud & Data Center Management
https://trevorsullivan.net
https://twitter.com/pcgeek86

comments.author: rkeithhill
comments.body: At the very least it would be nice if the error message surfaced the inner exception info.

comments.author: iSazonov
comments.body:
> Peer certificate cannot be authenticated with given CA certificates

It says that the server certificate is not valid. Should we add "DisableTLSCertificatesCheck"?

comments.author: SteveL-MSFT
comments.body: @iSazonov the `-SkipCertificateCheck` switch is a workaround, but we should have a better error message here

comments.author: iSazonov
comments.body:
> the  -SkipCertificateCheck  switch is a workaround

It can be useful with self-signed certificates.

comments.author: iSazonov
comments.body: Do it makes sense to open a new Issue about `-SkipCertificateCheck`?

comments.author: SteveL-MSFT
comments.body: @iSazonov can you be more specific about your issue with `-SkipCertificateCheck`?  It allows a self-sogned cert currently

comments.author: iSazonov
comments.body: I was not accurate. My idea is that if the browsers are doing warning about bad certificates but allow us to make the choice to continue or cancel then we have to do something similar.

comments.author: SteveL-MSFT
comments.body: @iSazonov so you want a prompt?  not sure how useful that is since I expect most uses of the webcmdlets to be in script rather than interactive.

comments.author: iSazonov
comments.body:
It seems a prompt may be breaking change.

I expect for request of URL with bad certificate:
1. By default - terminating error.
2. With  `-SkipCertificateCheck`  - warning.
